@prateekm @nickpan47 @xinyuiscool @vjagadish1989
@bharathkk  I think there may be some checkstyle errors. Check the jenkins build link.

@nickpan47  I believe we are bringing up multiple issues in this PR
1. Shared Zk node path between LocalApplicationRunner's leader election and JC's leader election
2. zkClient connection created in LocalApplicationRunner is not closed until the processor terminates.
3. Lack of our ability to distinguish between streamApplication restart Vs processor group membership change. The same latch remains open for every lifecycle of the application. 

Here is how I understand the current implementation of intermediate streams is behaving:
1. The first processor becomes the leader and completes the intermediate stream creation. Other processors block on the latch
2. If the leader succeeds in the critical operation, it will countdown latch and exit. Other processors that are blocked on the latch will get unblocked. However, since the zkclient connection is still left open, others processors become leader in-turn and repeat the operation.

What I believe is missing is that there is no **state** indicating that the critical operation was completed. Neither is there a validation of whether critical section operation has to be performed or not nor is there a clear distinction between application restart and processor restart. I believe we are trying to address this issue in PR #264  (fyi, I don't think the PR is complete). 

On the point about closing the zkClient connection after critical operation vs during processor shutdown:
* I don't see a lot of value in leaving the connection open after the ZK related operations are completed in the LAR layer. We don't want to continue receiving notifications on the processor group membership change after this phase
* Unnecessary n/w resource utilization
* This issues will get further magnified since we are not handling session timeouts in this layer and all event's from ZK will be handled in the event thread, thereby blocking the event thread itself. This may causes unexpected issues further down the road.

@navina and @bharathkk thanks for the detailed explanation on the issues. So, I just had a thought to address the long-idle ZK session:
what if we check the existence of the znode for the latch first before we enter the leader election section? Since the znode for the latch is persistent, that can serve as a barrier indicating that the stream creation phase is done. Then, we can have a short-lived ZK session for the stream creation.

Thanks @sborya ! The original import lines were importing Assert class with *, so there is nothing to remove there. 

Depending on the code style and best practice, most recommend not to use * to do wildcard matching (which I prefer), but some may think it is better to keep the existing style for consistency purpose. Anyway, we can discus about that one and determine an import practice horizontally for all files. For this PR, I think it is OK to not touch since it is out of the scope of the purpose.

@navina 
>Is it possible to add some kind of testing for orphaned containers problem itself ?

I wanted to do that before sending the patch for review. 

Scenario to test is interruption of a particular task (SamzaContainerLauncher) which gets triggered as effect on zk event sequence chain.

But all logic to spawn SamzaContainer in standalone is hidden within `StreamProcessor.createJobCoordinatorListener` (It's hard to pull that which in itself would require huge refactoring).

I was thinking to mimic `ZkJobCoordinator`/`StreamProcessor` logic to test interrupting a running samza conatiner within ScheduleDebounce thread. But that wouldn't test any of code flow.

Also, this scenario is very hard to test/control from public LocalApplicationRunner / ZkJobCoordinator api's.

Just one immediate comment before diving into code:

> I've made a choice here to disallow setting system/stream serdes in config to make configs simpler. Imho the 'serdes only in code' and 'only 2 levels of serde' model is much simpler to understand. The risk is that there might be streams that aren't part of the user application code, but need their serdes to be set in configuration. An example is the logging topic. Do you think this is a reasonable choice?

  for this. I think you've identified the only reason serdes should have ever been in config and imo we can find a way to configure them in code for the high-level-api

I assume nothing's changed for low level api. It's still config driven for all serdes, right?

@shanthoosh Merged this patch to 0.14.0 branch. You can close this PR. Thanks!

This patch looks useful, but looking at the description in the JIRA, I don't think it's sufficient.

1. When the system factory config exists but is an empty string, the class name is an empty string. So the log message in this patch won't be very informative. 
2. It would be better if the log message informed the user which system has the misconfigured system factory. 

One way to do that is to update SystemConfig.getSystemFactory() to validate against empty strings. 

Another option is to leverage some variant of ScalaMapConfig.getNonEmptyOption(), though that might cause us to silently ignore a configured system. So some adaptation would be required to instead print a log message.

@prateekm can you take another look? 

I feel pretty good about the change now. 
Fault testing has shown proper behavior with and without task.drop.producer.errors enabled for both user thread and callback thread exceptions. 

Performance testing shows a minor improvement for single threaded and compression disabled. It shows a big improvement for concurrency with compression enabled. I'll share some numbers on the JIRA tomorrow.

Discussed with @bharathkk offline. 
- The big difference in speed from 14s->4s comes from the removal of `Thread.sleep(10,000)`. 
- Using  `shutdown` is a first step to remove state sharing between tests and potentially enabling parallel execution later.

+1, Looks great!

I recommend at least the following two changes before merging to open source (for other enhancements, we can create jira tickets):

1) consolidate all 4 modules into a single samza-sql module. Current setup is a little bit too much, and the logic is spread across multiple modules. For any of the other platforms, like beam or flink, sql is just one module. For anything related  to user-level api, please move it to samza-api.

2) please simplify all the factories and configs into two: one for providing the calcite schema, the other is to provide the serde (avor <-> samzaRel). I think something like the following configs should be good enough:

-- streams.X.samza.sql.schema.factory=org.apache.samza.AvroRelSchemaFactory
-- streams.X.samza.sql.serde.factory=org.apache.samza.AvroRelSerdeFactory

You can add it on both stream and system level if needed (this is typical for other stream properties).

@jmakes Thanks for the feedback. I pushed another commit to utilize the `getNonEmptyOption()` method to return `None` if the class name is an empty string. This triggers the appropriate logging via `SamzaException`s and logs the misconfigured system factory.
@jmakes I was wondering why there are Scala and Java system config classes. I'll attempt some refactoring so other newbies don't have to walk the same path.

@cpettitt-linkedin @jmakes @nickpan47 @vjagadish1989, please take a look again.

Major Changes:
1. Changed the StreamGraph and MessageStream APIs such that they now work with both keyed and unkeyed streams. Only the 'repartition' (formerly partitionBy) operator enforces any key-value type restrictions. The rest depend on the type of Serde provided for the input/output stream.
2. Moved Serde classes from samza-core to samza-api.
3. Created a JsonSerdeV2 that useds the default ObjectMapper instead of SamzaObjectMapper.
4. Removed the restriction that users can't specify serdes in config. This is required for sinkTo to work since we don't control what streams they can output to. There are workarounds, but they're kinda hacky. Serdes provided in high level api code still take priority over those provided in configs.
@jmakes : could you please help take a look? Thanks!

@jmakes I'll defer to @nickpan47, but it looks like you're correct that `messages-in-flight` will keep increasing if the user never calls the callback methods. Also good point on 2.
@sborya could you please try committing again? I have added you to the svn access group.
@nickpan47 @jmakes FYI

@jmakes from the incidence that I saw, messages-in-flight stays as a constant positive number due to the fact that the process stalls when this number equals task.max.concurrency, which does not help much since in a full-throttle process, messages-in-flight may be a constant as well.

Good point on 2! I missed that. But I think that callbacks-completed metrics may still be helpful in the following situation (i.e. the one I caught previously during debugging some user code):
- task.callback.timeout.ms is not set
- user missed the call TaskCallback.complete() on completion
Mainly, if the container stuck w/ process-calls = 0 and callback-completed = 0 and messages-in-flight != 0, we can conclude that the container got stuck due to callback.complete() is never triggered. Make sense?

@nickpan47 

> user missed the call TaskCallback.complete() on completion
Mainly, if the container stuck w/ process-calls = 0 and callback-completed = 0 and messages-in-flight != 0, we can conclude that the container got stuck due to callback.complete() is never triggered. Make sense?

Well, process-calls is incremented before invoking the user process(), so I don't think that scenario can occur, exactly. Instead process-calls = 1, and messages-in-flight = 1. 

To me, if process-calls is not increasing and messages-in-flight stays non-zero for the same duration, we can conclude that it's stuck, right?
oh, interesting. I will add volatile.
@xinyuiscool @sborya can you guys take a look?
cc @vjagadish1989 for review.

Synced up with @jmakes offline. We agreed that this task level callback-completed would be useful to debug that a certain task stuck w/ failing. Hence, we are only adding this one metric in TaskInstanceMetrics and removing the failure counts.
@nickpan47 I removed the async container level metrics and left only the async completed metric at the task level per your discussion with @jmakes. Ready for another review!

Semicolons; semicolons everywhere!

cc @vjagadish1989 @xinyuiscool @jmakes for review.
